titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Carl F. Schreiber Papers
titlestmt.author: by Christa Sammons

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 05:37

did.unittitle: Carl F. Schreiber papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Carl F. Schreiber Papers consist of material generated by Schreiber as curator of the William A. Speck Collection at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library and as a Yale faculty member. The bulk of the papers were left in the library when Schreiber retired; some material has been brought to the library by the Yale German Department and by occupants of the Palmer Schreiber Library in Bingham Tower. Material includes personal papers, correspondence, writing and research files, and writings by others, documenting Schreiber's research and curatorial activities which largely focused on the German authors Harro Harring and Goethe.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Carl F. Schreiber Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Carl F. Schreiber Papers. Yale Collection of German Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing in 2007-2008, including partial rehousing and minimal organization.

bioghist.head: Carl Frederick Schreiber (1886-1960)
bioghist.p: Carl F. Schreiber was born in Saginaw, Michigan. His father, Hugo Friedrich, was a merchant; his mother was Adelaide Rueter. Schreiber received his B.A. from the University of Michigan in 1907, his M.A. from New York University in 1910, and his Ph.D. from Yale University in 1914. His dissertation, which remained unpublished, was entitled "Harro Harring: ein Beitrag zur Demagogenliteratur." After teaching German at an Illinois high school and at New York University, Schreiber came to Yale in 1909 as an instructor. By 1926 he had been promoted to full professor, and in 1928 he succeeded William A. Speck as curator of the William A. Speck Collection of Goetheana. In 1936 he was named the Leavenworth Professor of German Languages & Literatures. He retired from his faculty position in 1954 but stayed on as curator until his death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Carl F. Schreiber Papers consist of material generated by Schreiber as curator of the William A. Speck Collection at the Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library and as a Yale faculty member. The bulk of the papers were left in the library when Schreiber retired; some material has been brought to the library by the Yale German Department and by occupants of the Palmer Schreiber Library in Bingham Tower. Material includes personal papers, correspondence, writing and research files, and writings by others, documenting Schreiber's research and curatorial activities which largely focused on the German authors Harro Harring and Goethe.

Schreiber's general professional correspondence is contained in the office correspondence of the Yale Collection of German Literature, where beginning in the 1940s it was interfiled with letters by Curt von Faber du Faur and Hedwig S. Dejon. Only letters strictly connected with specific projects and his correspondence relating to his research on Harro Harring and on Edgar Allan Poe have been classed here with his papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into three series: I. Personal and family papers, circa 1912-1935. II. Writings and research projects, circa 1910-1957. III. Writings by others, circa 1930s.

did.unittitle: Personal and family papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included are primarily scrapbooks and files relating to Schreiber's trips to Germany.

The scrapbooks contain newspaper clippings pasted in three columns per page. The clippings, dating from the 1890s, principally in German, some in English, are pasted on the pages of used ledger books of the 1870s from a business involving some sort of metered commodity. The prevalence of women's topics in the religion and poetry volumes suggests that the scrapbooks may have been compiled by a woman, possibly Schreiber's mother. A religious poem entitled "Take some part" near the end of the poetry volume is inscribed "Carl's recitative 1900."

The files documenting Schreiber's trips to Germany in the 1930s contain a variety of travel-related correspondence, programs, invitations, and post cards. In 1931 he appears to have carried the Speck Collection items illustrated in the Speck portfolio of 1932 and catalog of 1940 to Germany, where the facsimiles were produced. In 1932 (the centenary of Goethe's death) he gave a radio speech in Germany. The 1934 trip was a tour sponsored by the Carl Schurz Foundation for American educators and students. Schreiber's wife and daughter accompanied him in 1935.

Writings and research projects

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into ten subseries: Lectures and speeches; Reviews; Writings on German literature; Harro Harring: research materials, correspondence, thesis; Fiction and Fantasty; Speck portfolio; Minimum German; Speck catalog, 1940; The "Chicago" Goethe; and Edgar Allen Poe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: While Schreiber's doctoral research was on Harro Harring (1798-1870), he never published his dissertation on this radical writer and political agitator. His scholarly career and writing were instead devoted largely to Goethe, reflecting his association with the Speck Collection for some three decades.

Schreiber's research materials on Harro Harring are described in more detail than the rest of the papers. This section was described earlier for the information of the late Thomas Thode, whose Harring bibliography appeared in 2005.

As curator of the Speck Collection, Schreiber was deeply involved in two of its major publications, Goetheana. A centenary portfolio of forty-three facsimiles and reproductions of unique or rare items from the William A Speck Collection of Goetheana , and Goethe's works with the exception of Faust: A catalogue compiled by members of the Yale University Library staff , published by the Yale University Press in 1932 and 1940 respectively. The latter, conceived along the lines of the Katalog der Sammlung Kppenberg (2nd edition, Leipzig: Insel, 1928), was intended as a four-volume set, but no more was ever issued. (Volume 2 was to have described the collection's Faust holdings; volume 3 was to have contained biographical material about Goethe; and volume 4 was to have brought addenda and a much-needed index.)

The publishing history of the Portfolio and the Catalogue are bound together by the facsimiles contained in each. In 1931, Schreiber carried 43 items from the Speck Collection to Germany, where facsimiles were made by Albrecht Frisch, a printer in Berlin who specialized in photoengraving and who had worked on the catalog of the Kippenberg Collection. The facsimiles were produced in sets of 1,000 copies each. Five-hundred from each set were issued as the Portfolio in 1932; eight years later, the other 500 copies of seventeen of the facsimiles were bound into the first volume of the Catalogue . The other 26 sets of facsimiles have been preserved for years, and although the paper is now brittle and unsuitable to be bound in any book, the curator resisted various attempts to discard the remaining facsimiles. (She has distributed some of them in various ways as pertinent occasions arose, so most sets are incomplete.) Sets of the Frisch facsimiles in various formats are preserved in the Schreiber papers, along with correspondence about their production.

Also scheduled for publication in the centenary year 1932 was a proposed two-volume essay collection called "Goethe in America." In the mid-1920s Schreiber and his Yale colleague Adolph B. Benson began to collect papers and prepare them for publication, but in the end funds to print the book could not be raised. Seventeen papers are present in the collection, some of them by major scholars of the time, along with a file of correspondence, plans, and outlines.

Another scholarly project that came to naught was the so-called "Chicago" (later "Yale") Goethe. The history and background of this initiative is outlined in a letter from Victor Lange to Heinz Blum, dated 29 March 1954 in Box 10. In 1948, a group of scholars (Schreiber, Victor Lange, Arnold E. Bergraesser), anticipating the bicentennial of Goethe's birth, entered negotiations with the University of Chicago Press to publish a 4-volume edition of Goethe's works in new English translations. After some difficulties, documented in the collection by the example of Schreiber's translation of Goethe's Novelle, the University of Chicago Press transferred its contracts to the Henry Regnery Company, then also in Chicago; that contract is dated 1952. The arrangement with Henry Regnery apparently failed, and in 1954 Heinz Blum, chairman of the Yale German Department, attempted to revive the project as the "Yale" Goethe, to be published in 12 volumes by the Yale University Press. Financial subvention was promised by Frederick von Schleinitz, and the project seemed to be getting underway (without Schreiber's collaboration, however), but the documentation ends abruptly in 1957 and no volumes of "Yale" Goethe were ever published.

Materials in the Schreiber papers, although fragmentary, show that the translation of Dichtung und Wahrheit was well underway in the late 1940s: Minna Steel Smith's English version (London, 1908), itself based on the Oxenford/Morrison translation of 1849, was typed out in several copies and used as a basic text. Schreiber and his collaborators, Wallace J. Williamson and Jane Bannard Greene, made revisions. A version conflated from their various changes was being retyped and submitted to the University of Chicago Press. Not all copies for all sections of the book are preserved, but the typescripts present for Book XIII illustrate the working process. The Götz translation may belong to the Yale phase of the project; that play is not listed in the University of Chicago Press contracts.

Schreiber's interest in Edgar Allan Poe dates to the summer of 1925, when he went to New York City to examine Superior Court records. While looking for documents relating to a suit that Harro Harring had brought against Harper and Brothers in 1846 (Harring, it will be remembered, was the subject of Schreiber's dissertation), he found instead the records of Poe's suit against the owners of the New York Evening Mirror , documents previously unknown to Poe scholars. Around this time Schreiber made Poe the focus of his personal book collecting: he set out to gather every book of which Poe had published a review, some 240 titles. Schreiber published at least two substantial articles about Poe: "A close-up of Poe" in The Saturday Review of Literature for 9 October 1926, and "Mr. Poe at his conjurations again" the The Colophon , 1930. The Schreiber papers retain other Poe materials, including Schreiber's essay "Poe and Goethe," which is related textually to "Mr. Poe at his conjurations again." Schreiber seems also to have devoted a good deal of research to prove Poe's role in the compilation of The Laws of Etiquette (Philadephia: Carey, Lea, and Blanchard, 1836) and on an essay called "The Canon of Good Breeding."

A small convolute of typed transcriptions concerning the composer Robert Lucas Pearsall from well-known periodicals and reference books was discarded; Schreiber's interest in Pearsall may have been due to the fact that Pearsall made an attempt to translate Faust .

scopecontent.p: Contained within this folder are typed excerpts from a longer work with numbered sections up to at least 108, 4 leaves. In the same folder: "Nachträge zu Heine's Reisebildern," with the imprint information Hoffmann und Campe, 1831, and the note "Harring's Erstling in Gebiete der Recension!" 5 leaves.

did.unittitle: Briefe über die Vereinigten Staaten Nordamerikas, in Bezug auf ihr Verhältnis zur Europäischen Revolution und zum Kampfe im Orient, 1854. Transcript in the hand of Johann Sass, 131 numbered leaves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the same folder, another group of poems, apparently drawn from several sources, typed and in Schreiber's hand and another American hand. 14 leaves.

did.unittitle: Blutstrophen. Deutsche Gedichte (1832). Typed transcript, 17 leaves with some marginal notes in Schreiber's hand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the same folder, other poems: Es ist kein Traum. Handwritten transcript, 3 p.; An Mazzini. Transcript in Schreiber's hand, 4 p.; Nimmer nach Amerika. Transcript in Schreiber's hand, 2 p.; Der Völkerfreund. Transcript in Schreiber's hand, 3 p.; Der Bundestag. Transcript inSchreiber's hand, 1 p.; Mein Vaterland! Transcript in Schreiber's hand, 2 p.; Das Bild der Rose. Typed transcript with marginalia by Schreiber, 2 p.; "Politische Lieder aus dem 2. Stück "Das Volk." Typed transcript with a few marginalia by Schreiber, 5 p. (excerpts? Indications of: Seite 142, 161, 194, 233, 235).

did.unittitle: Deutschland. Excerpts from the newspaper, many dated 1831-32, some typed, most in Schreiber's hand, 18 leaves

Es ist kein Traum! (later title of the poem written for the "Hambacher Fest" of May 1832). Notes and transcripts in Schreiber's hand and another American hand, 6 leaves. With two photostats identified as "Hambacher Fest, Pictures."
Faust im Gewande der Zeit (1831). Reading notes and remarks in Schreiber's hand, 4 leaves; typed transcript of the beginning of the publication, 2 leaves.

The Funeral of Goethe. From the German of Harro Harring. Translation by Alexamder H. Everett (Democratic Review, Nov. 1842). Translation of the poem "Göthe" in Die Möwe (See Thode, p. 101). Typed transcript, 6 p. (XV stanzas); handwritten copy of German (American hand).

Gedanken über Wahrheit (1832). Typed transcription, 10 numbered leaves. In the same folder, notes and excerpts from Worte eines Menschen. Dem Gläubigen von La Mennais gewidmet (1834), in Schreiber's hand, continued in another American hand, 2 leaves.
Mémoires sur la Jeune Italie et sur les dernier événemens de Savoie (1834). Transcript in the hand of Schreiber (through page 108). Ends "Harro Harring, Le 27 juillet 1834," 18 leaves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These folders contain the following related materials: An excerpt headed: "General Dufour" in der Savoyer Putsch von 1834. Von Prof. Dr. Alfred Stern," in Schreiber's hand, 4 leaves.; Proclamation. Soldats! Soldati! Savoy, 31 Jan. 1834. Broadside in French and Italian. Photostat from the Haus-Hof-und-Staats-Archiv, Wien.

did.unittitle: "Mitteilungen über Russland. Von Harro Harring. N Y. Criminal Zeitung." Typed transcript with title (on the wrapper) in Johann Sass's hand, 34 numbered pages.

"Die Möwe . . . Neu aufgelegt von mehreren Deutschen" (1840). Transcription of title page and preface by J Garnier, in another American hand, 2 leaves. Transcription of poems "Die Möwe" and "Navarino" in Schreiber's hand, 2 leaves. Transcription of a review of the book (Schlsewig. Holst. Blätter) in Schreiber's hand, 1 leaf.
"Notizen zum Verzeichnis meiner sämmtlichen Schriften. Für Oscar Falke, Louis Fricker, Theodor Remi etc." Transcription in the hand of Johann Sass, 5 double leaves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The copy is evidently made from a manuscript: several places are marked "unleserlich."

did.unittitle: "Der Renegat auf Morea." (1831). Excerpts in Schreiber's hand, 6 leaves, with 2 leaves of notes, one of them in Schreiber's hand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the same folder, notes and transcripts relating to Die Mainotten (1825) and Der Corsar (1825), 9 leaves. The folder is labeled "Philhellener-Drama."

did.unittitle: "Die Schwarzen von Giessen" (1831). Partial transcription, mostly in Schreiber's hand, some passages in the other American hand, 23 leaves.
"Skizze aus London" (1838). Transcriptions, typed, in Schreiber's hand and in the other American hand, 15 leaves.
"La Telyn (Harpe) d'un Scandinave" (1839). Excerpts in Schreiber's hand, 4 leaves.
"Die Völker" (1832). Excerpt in Schreiber's hand, 5 leaves.
"Das Volk. Dramatische Szenen zur Darstellung durch Volksfreunde" (1832). Transcription, partly typed, partly handwritten, mostly by Schreiber, some passages in another American hand, ca. 72 leaves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the same folder, partial typed transcription of the poem "Peter Wisozki, der edle Pole" (1832), 1 leaf.

Harro Harring: letters

":Originals" - ALS to "Lieber Freund." Schestedt bei Rendsburg. 19 April 1849, 7 pages on two folded leaves (original). With ALS to "Lieber Bruder." Kiel, 1 August 1821 (photostat), and a manuscript poem titled "Schiller's Triumph in Leipzig, signed Adlph Böttger, with a presentation inscription dated 1927 to Schreiber from his grandfather.
"Briefe an Johanna Mesdorf (Später Direktor des Museums Vaterländischer Altertümer in Kiel," 1848-1853. Handwritten transcription, 34 numbered pages

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This material is in the same paper as Sass transcripts below, but not in his hand.

did.unittitle: "Briefe an Todsen." 1821-43. Transcriptions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Leaves numbered 1-257 and 1-105 in a hand resembling J. Sass's; 1-66 in a different (German) hand. Another set of transcripts, typed, 1833-38; these appear to be letters not represented in the handwritten transcript.

did.unittitle: "Briefe an Todsen." 1821-43. Transcriptions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Leaves numbered 1-257 and 1-105 in a hand resembling J. Sass's; 1-66 in a different (German) hand. Another set of transcripts, typed, 1833-38; these appear to be letters not represented in the handwritten transcript.

did.unittitle: Transcripts of letters by Harring then owned by Johann Sass. In Sass's hand, with a covering letter from him, Berlin, 12 April 1928. 27 single and double leaves, each representing one letter.
Convolute of letters by and to Harring, including correspondence with his brother, with Todsen, to "Justizrat von Starkenburg [reading of St and k doubtful]. Handwritten transcriptions.
Harro Harring: documentary materials

"Briefe von Harro Harring, oder am Harro H., wie sie in den periodischen Berichten der Polizei-Notizen zu finden sind (1852)." Typed transcripts with titles and annotations in the hand of Johann Sass(?), 20 leaves.
Notes concerning Harring's activities in 1835 and a poem entitled "Lied der Liebe," also dated 1835. Typed transcripts, annotated in Sass's (?) hand.
"Notes from Geheimes Staatsarchiv, Berlin-Dahlem." Transcripts, mostly in Schreiber's hand, 59 half leaves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder also contains a TLS from M. Klinkenberg (Geheimes Staats-Archiv) to Schreiber, Berlin-Dahlem, 13 April 1928, 1 leaf, concerning arrangements for Schreiber to work in archives in Vienna.

did.unittitle: "Schäfer, Berichte aus Paris, after returning from London 26 Nov. 1838 and 6 Dez. 1839 [folder title]."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains a series of transcribed reports headed "Beilage zum Bericht Noés aus Mainz vom [various dates], followed by a series number and a dateline from Paris, generally a few days earlier than the Mainz date. Typed and in a German hand, ca. 77 leaves. With an ALS from Fritz Antonius to Schreiber ("Herr Professor"), Vienna, 20 March 1929 describing his work on these materials.

did.unittitle: Harro Harring: secondary literature
"Erzählendes." Transcripts of contemporary notices and reviews of Harring's fiction, in Schreiber's and another American hand, 12 leaves.
[Gelzer, Heinrich] Die geheimen deutschen Verbindungen in der Schweiz sein 1833 (Basel, 1847). Typed excerpts with annotation in Schreiber's hand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Other excerpts in the folder, presumably from the same book, include "Die Religion der Zukunft," 1 p.; "Herwegh und Follen," 2 pages, typed, annotated by Schreiber; "Freiligrath und die Tendenz," 1 leaf; and 20 leaves of handwritten excerpts (and notes?).

did.unittitle: Marr, Wilhelm. Das junge Deutschland in der Schweitz (1846). Typed excerpts annotated in Schreiber's hand, 14 leaves.
Sass, Johann. "Zur Lebensgeschichte Harro Harrings." Sonderdruck aus "Die Heimat." (marked "Okt. 27"), 4 p.
Schreiber, Carl F. Two chapters of his dissertation on Harring (in German).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first chapter is an account of Harring's life through 1832. The second is entitled "Polen." The typescripts appear to be from different drafts (the orthography differs—in the second chapter, nouns are not capitalized.) Chapter I: 13 leaves; "Polen": 28 leaves. Both with handwritten changes.

did.unittitle: Schweizer, Paul. Geschichte der schweizerischen Neutralitaet. (Zürich, 1895). Typed excerpt, 29 leaves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One leaf is handwritten and may belong in "Mémoires sur la Jeune Italie . . ."

did.unittitle: Harro Harring: miscellaneous
"Allgemein Politisches [folder title]."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains typed and handwritten notes and excerpts from various sources, some contemporary with Harring, 12 leaves.

did.unittitle: "Harring, Harro, Allgemeines [folder heading]."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains an assortment of notes and excerpts on various German literary figures, partly typed, partly in Schreiber's hand.

did.unittitle: La giovine Italia . . . 1o Trimestre – 1o Fascicolo. Marsiglia, 1832. [16] p., original wrappers.
"Das junge Deutschland [folder title]."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains the following material: Two blue notebooks, in Schreiber's hand, with titles "Das revolutionäre Europa im Spiegel d. deut. Lit. (1817-1848)" and "Revolution II. Vortrag."; Typed outline, "Das junge Deutschland. May 31, 1930," l leaf, with a page of bibliography.; Typed transcription of a letter from Carlyle to Rev. W. Jacobson, 23 Aug. 1840, concerning Mazzini.

did.unittitle: Littlefield, Walter. Review of Mazzini: Prophet of Modern Europe, by Gwilym O. Griffith (NY: Harcourt, Brace). Clipping from The New York Times Book Review.
"Philhellenismus – Allgemeines [folder title]." Assorted notes, typed and handwritten, on this topic, including bibliography and excerpts from secondary literature.
Negative photostats from the British Library and the New York Public Library
Schreiber's correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The following correspondence relates to Schreiber's research on Harro Harring and is in roughly chronological order.

did.unittitle: Harring, Therese. ALS, APCS, autograph poem, and clipping.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Therese Harring was the Niece of Harro Harring.

did.unittitle: American Express Company. TLS, concerning archival records from Jersey, Channel Islands
Houben, H.H. TLS, Harring material in Berlin Staatsarchiv
Frankenburg, Richard. ALS
British Museum, TLS, response to reference query
Sass, Johann. APCS. Berlin, New Year's greeting
Elliott, Maud Howe, TLS to Schreiber. Palm Beach, FL, 31 Jan. 1935, 1 leaf, with his reply, TL (copy) [New Haven] 6 Feb. 1935.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The exchange has to do with Schreiber's efforts to establish that Mrs. Elliot's uncle, Sam Ward, was the same as the one married to Meodora Ward, to whom the American edition of Dolores was dedicated. With typed transcript of a letter from Harring to Mrs. Ward, New York, 5 March 1846, 2 leaves. Related to the following folder:

did.unittitle: "Harro Harring vs. Harper Bros. [folder heading]."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and other notes relating to Schreiber's attempt to find the records of the 1846 lawsuit between Harring and Harper Bros. concerning the novel Dolores. Also correspondence relating to Schreiber's attempt to identify Meodora Ward, to whom the novel is dedicated. With apparently unrelated correspondence asking various U.S. libraries about their holdings in titles by Harring.

did.unittitle: Pauls, V. 2 TLS to Schreiber. Kiel, 30 April and 25 July 1929, 4 p. stamped "Schlesw.-Holstein. Landesbibliothek"), with typed list, "Verzeichnis der Manuskripte Harro Harrings in der Schleswig-Holsteinischen Landesbibliothek, Kiel, compiled by Dr. [Richard] Frankenberg, 2 p. (carbon copy).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Schreiber was to send back a copy of the list indicating which manuscripts he wished to have transcribed. With copies of Schreiber's letters to Pauls, 29 Jan., 16 April, and 27 May 1929.

did.unittitle: Pauls, V. TLS to Schreiber. Kiel, 29 March 1939. 2 p., letter head of the Gesellschaft für Schleswig-Holsteinische Geschichte.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inquires about the progress of Schreiber's Harring research. Notes that Dr. Frankenberg has been drawn away from his research by other responsibilities, but is now in a position to work on Harring again.

did.unittitle: Bülck, Rudolf. TLS to Schreiber. Kiel, 8 Sept. 1948, 1 p.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Asks for Schreiber's advice about a Harring letter owned by Wilhelm Ladewig, subsequently published by Ladewig as "Harro Harrings Brief aus Cowes of Wright vom 23. Mai 1848" in Jb. des Nordfriesischen Instituts, Jg. 1 (1949). Bülck identifies himself as Bibliotheksrat at the university library in Kiel.

did.unittitle: Ladewig, Wilhelm. 2 TLS to Schreiber. Dörpling, 4 and 9 Oct. 1948, 2 p.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sends two articles, offers to collaborate. The second letter encloses a list, "Material über Harro Harring im Besitz von Wilhelm Ladewig," 1 leaf. The letters refer to earlier correspondence.

did.unittitle: Glaser, Hermann. 2 TLS to Schreiber. Nürnberg, undated and 6 Nov. 1951. With Schreiber's responses, 31 Oct. 1951 and 27 Jan.1952.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence relates to Schreiber's article "Hamlet ist Deutschland," (PMLA, 1913) but includes an account of his career and why he wrote no more about Harro Harring (intervention of the First World War, lack of time afterwards).

did.unittitle: Two large glass negatives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These negatives showing (1) portraits of Harring, Maltits, Heine, and Börne and (2) another portrait (of Harring in old age?).

did.unittitle: Schreiber, assorted notes, autograph and typed, on half sheets
Fiction and Fantasy, 1927

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drafts and paste-ups for the book Fiction and fantasy of German romance; Selections from the German Romantic authors, 1790-1830, in English translation, edited by Frederick E. Pierce . . . and Carl F. Schreiber (New York, etc.: Oxford University Press, 1927.

did.unittitle: Speck portfolio, 1932

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Goetheana. A centenary portfolio of forty-three facsimiles and reproductions of unique or rare items from the William A Speck collection of Goetheana (Yale University Press, 1932). Included are typescript and proofs, production figures and costs, advertising prospectuses, reviews, correspondence, reactions and alternate cover mock-ups and set of facsimiles.

did.unittitle: Minimum German, 1935

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and documents relating to the book Minimum German by Schreiber and Nils G. Sahlin (New York: F. S. Crofts & Co, 1935)

did.unittitle: Speck catalog, 1940. Goethe's Works with the Exception of Faust(Yale University Press, 1940)
Volume I
Drafts of Schreiber's introduction
Production of the facsimiles: plans, lists, documents from Albert Frisch Verlag, Berlin
Production with the Yale University Press: plans, correspondence, samples, etc.
Suggestions by Alfred Bergmann

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Alfred Bergmann had just re-edited the Kippenberg Goethe catalog.

did.unittitle: Financial documents & complimentary copies
Reprint of Speck biography
Reviews
Volume II (Faust): Plans, correspondence, etc. including letters relating to Vera Lachmann's proposed work on the project
Volume III: Card index relating to proposed contents
The "Chicago" Goethe, 1948-57
Contracts and correspondence: Schreiber, Victor Lange, Arnold E. Bergraesser, University of Chicago Press, Henry Regnery Company, Heinz Blum, Frederick von Schleinitz, James Babb, etc.
Goethe. Novelle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript translation by Schreiber, in many copies, with suggested changes by several persons

did.unittitle: Goethe. The Campaign in France 1792.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Translated by Jane Bannard Greene and Heinz Norden.

did.unittitle: Goethe. Dichtung und Wahrheit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Translated by Minna Steele Smith with revisions by Schreiber, Wallace J. Williamson, and Jane Bannard Greene. With a folder of contracts, readers' reports, and correspondence

did.unittitle: Goethe. Dichtung und Wahrheit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Translated by Minna Steele Smith with revisions by Schreiber, Wallace J. Williamson, and Jane Bannard Greene. With a folder of contracts, readers' reports, and correspondence

did.unittitle: Goethe. Faust I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unidentified, incomplete translation, in an unidentified hand and typed

did.unittitle: Goethe. Götz von Berlichingen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Various corrected typescripts, Act 1 only

did.unittitle: Edgar Allan Poe
Schreiber. "A close-up of Poe." Saturday Review of Literature 3:11 (1926), printed version
Schreiber. "Mr Poe at his conjurations again." The Colophon," 1930. Drafts and printed version
Schreiber. "Poe and Goethe." Typescript (related textually to above); another typescript filed with the "Goethe in America" project
Schreiber. "Mr. Poe gets up books." Typescripts
[Schreiber?]"Poe Flurries." Incomplete typescript
[Schreiber?] [Essay on Poe]. Typescript
Schreiber. "Poe works in periodicals." Typescript
Schreiber. "Henry Beck Hirst." Drafts, typescript
Schreiber. "A few works on etiquette." Typed notes (for a lecture?)
Federmann, Arnold. "Johann Heinrich Füssli und Edgar Allan Poe." Typescript
Correspondence relating to Poe
Writings by others
Yale graduate student papers from the 1930s. Typescripts, unless otherwise noted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These folders contain the following papers: Blume, Albert M. K. (Ph.D. 1940). "First English translation in America of Goethe's 'Götz von Berlichingen,'" 1934; Eastman, Anthony Dey (Ph.D. 1935). "Goethe and the French Revolution," 20 April 1932; Gemeinhardt, Lawrence (Ph.D. 1940). "Goethe and Werther after 1774"; Hanrahan, William R., Jr. (MA, 1942). "The effects of Goethe's Werther in England"; Hegeman, Daniel V. B. (Ph.D, 1934). Dissertation defense, autograph ms., with questions in Schreiber's hand. The dissertation was entitled "The Cultural Background of Classical Weimar Studies in the Modenjournal of Bertuch and Kraus, 1786- 1806"; McKenzie, Earl D (Ph.D. 1935). "The problem of the pseudo-Goethean poem 'Joseph,'" 15 June 1934; Scholz, Albert (Ph.D., 1942). "Sturm und Drang in 'Götz von Berlichingen,'" 13 June 1934; Tiller, Fritz (Ph.D, 1940). "Faust und Werther als die beiden Pols des Sturms und Drangs," June 1934; Zerner, Marianne (Ph.D. 1939). "Ueber die Entstehungsgeschichte des Urfausts".

did.unittitle: Goethe in America
Correspondence, plans and outlines

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Articles in typescript, some with correspondence:

did.unittitle: Church, Howard W, "Henry Irving's Faust in America"
Eastburn, Iola Kay. "Whittier and Goethe"
Heller, Clarence Nevin. "The Goethean Literary Society of Franklin and Marshall College"

Ladd, Benjamin F., and Adolph B. Benson. "Goethe biography in America"
Lehnert, Frederick O., and Adolph B. Benson. "Percival and Goethe"
Leyen, Friedrich von der. "Goethe and world literature"
Long, Orie William. "Werther in America"
Raschen, J. F. L. "Lewis Morrison and his 'Faust' production in America"
_____. "Emerson and Goethe"
Rose, William. [correspondence only]
Schreiber, Carl F. "Poe and Goethe"
Schwarze, William Nathaniel. "Goethe's contacts with the Moravian Church"
Selmer, Carl. "Goethe celebrations in America"
Shelley, Philip A. "Goethe in the American annuals and gift-books"
Voss, Ernst. "Goethe monuments in America"
Wadepuhl, Walter. "Goethe's interest in the New World"`
Zeydel, Edwin H. "Translations of Goethe's works in America"
Papers by colleagues in the field. Typescripts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains the following papers: Anon. "The first translation of Werther."; Aron, Willi. "The mature Goethe and Rousseau"; Curtius, Ernst Robert. "Goethes Aktenführung." Signed offprint; Morente. "Goethe und die hispanische Welt"; Reinsch, F. J. "Problems in current Goethe research"; Spann, Meno. "Mephistopheles (ante spectators)"; Trevelyan, Humphrey. "Goethe as thinker," with corresp. ca. 1936; Wadepuhl, Walter. "Amerika, du hast es besser".
